title: Adding on-graph labels
text: Coloured labels placed directly plot better graph legends making final, polished version graph presentations, notes papers three key reasons. Labels make much easier reader identify group colour corresponds , without rapid eye twitch graph legend back . Repeat every group present graph soon recipe eyestrain. Labels make efficient use available space graph removing need make room legend. Legends create unused white space around legend element force plot shorter narrower otherwise . Finally, labels aesthetic legends.

title: Adding on-graph labels
text: simplest way add plot labels use plot_label() function theme61. following code provides example. code set mock data create graph, two lines important plot_label() lines. plot_label() requires provide text label (label), x y positioning, total number different colours/labels plot (n_labs), number element currently plotting (n). information, see documentation (?plot_label). multiple labels may efficient use mplot_label(), introduced next section.
code: # Mock data graph_data <- CJ(   x = 2000:2020,   source = c("Source A", "Source B") )  graph_data[source == "Source A", y := seq(0, by = 0.25, length = 21)] graph_data[source == "Source B", y := seq(0, by = 1, length = 21)]  # Graph graph <- ggplot(graph_data, aes(x, y, colour = source)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   plot_label(label = "Source A", x = 2017, y = 6, n_labs = 2, n = 1) +   plot_label(label = "Source B", x = 2017, y = 13, n_labs = 2, n = 2) +   theme_e61() +   scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(0, 20, 5)) +   scale_colour_e61(2) +   labs_e61(     title = "Simple Case Using plot_label()",     sources = c("e61 Institute"),     x = NULL, y = "n"   )  save_e61(here::here("man/figures/label-fig-1.svg"), graph) knitr::include_graphics(here::here("man/figures/label-fig-1.svg"))

title: Adding on-graph labels
text: multiple plot labels, mplot_label() allows add one function. using function, make sure wording vector label names label argument exactly colour/fill aesthetic plotted, order label vector matches order colour/fill aesthetic ordering colours. One way ensure setting column data ordered factor, calling label names using levels(data$col_name).
code: # Mock data graph_data <- CJ(   x = 2000:2020,   source = ordered(c("Source A", "Source B")) )  graph_data[source == "Source A", y := seq(0, by = 0.25, length = 21)] graph_data[source == "Source B", y := seq(0, by = 1, length = 21)]  # Graph graph <- ggplot(graph_data, aes(x, y, colour = source)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1) +   mplot_label(     label = levels(graph_data$source),     x = c(2017, 2017),     y = c(6, 13)   ) +   theme_e61() +   scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(0, 20, 5)) +   scale_colour_e61(2) +   labs_e61(     title = "Multiple Labels Using mplot_label()",     sources = c("e61 Institute"),     x = NULL, y = "n"   )  save_e61(here::here("man/figures/label-fig-2.svg"), graph) knitr::include_graphics(here::here("man/figures/label-fig-2.svg"))

title: Adding on-graph labels
text: faceted graph, using plot_label() mplot_label() work properly. annotations appear position facets way prevent . problematic labels unnecessarily repeating , correct position text one facet may different facet (e.g. height columns differs across facets). way get around problem using data.frame approach labelling graph. data.frame approach uses helper data.frame contains information needed plot text uses geom_text() add text graph. addition label text, x y positions, also need include facet column data.frame. Note provide one facets, case “”. Notice also set column factor column two levels, “” “B”. step important, internally plot graph label facet “”, goes plot labels facet “B” missing hence nothing plotted. aside, want put one label first facet second label another facet, facet column, simply allocate first label “” second “B”.
code: # Mock data graph_data <- data.frame(   facet = c("A", "A", "B", "B"),   x = 1,   y = c(10, 15, 10, 15),   group = c("P", "Q", "P", "Q") )  graph_labels <- data.frame(   x = c(0.75, 1.25),   y = c(12, 17),   group = c("P", "Q"),   facet = factor("A", c("A", "B")) )  # Graph graph <- ggplot(graph_data, aes(x, y, fill = group)) +   facet_wrap(~facet) +   geom_col(position = "dodge") +   # This geom_text adds the labels   # The label arg add the text, the colour arg ensures the text colour matches    # the lines they are identifying.   geom_text(data = graph_labels, aes(x, y, label = group, colour = group)) +   theme_e61() +   scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(0, 20, 5)) +   scale_colour_e61(2) +   scale_fill_e61(2) +   labs_e61(     title = "Facetted Case Using a Helper data.frame",     sources = c("e61 Institute"),     x = NULL, y = "n"   )  save_e61(here::here("man/figures/label-fig-3.svg"), graph) knitr::include_graphics(here::here("man/figures/label-fig-3.svg"))

title: Adding on-graph labels
text: Sometimes many categories, far many want plot manually even data.frame approach. willing sacrifice ability specify exact location label, use geom_text_repel() add appropriately coloured text labels colour/fill aesthetic.
code: # Mock data graph_data <- CJ(   year = 2000:2020,   source = paste("Source", LETTERS[1:5]) ) graph_data[, value := sample(5, nrow(graph_data), replace = TRUE)]  # Graph graph <- ggplot(graph_data, aes(x = year, y = value, fill = source)) +   geom_area(linewidth = 1) +                   # We only need one label for each group, ideally on the far                    # right of the graph, so we keep the last year only   geom_text_repel(data = graph_data[year == max(year)],                   aes(x = year, y = value, label = source, colour = source),                   # This forces the text to appear further right than 2020                   xlim = c(2020, NA),                   # This moves the vertical position of the label downwards                   position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5),                   # This hides the line that joins the label to the graph element                   segment.color = NA,                   size = 4) +   theme_e61(fix_left = 3) +   # Extends the right-side of the graph to create room for the labels   scale_x_continuous(limits = c(NA, 2026)) +   scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(0, 25, 5)) +   scale_fill_e61(5) +   scale_colour_e61(5) +   labs_e61(     title = "Use geom_text_repel to Show Many Labels Automatically",     sources = c("e61 Institute"),     x = NULL, y = "n"   )  save_e61(here::here("man/figures/label-fig-4.svg"), graph) knitr::include_graphics(here::here("man/figures/label-fig-4.svg"))

title: Introduction to theme61
text: theme61 acts extension ggplot2. made custom theme variety functions change appearance standard ggplot2 graph. Thus, correct usage package create normal ggplot2 graph, add theme61-specific elements. article provides examples help figure elements can change. Refer examples function reference page see full scope package.

title: Introduction to theme61
code: # Set up data mtcars2 <- within(mtcars, {   vs <- factor(vs, labels = c("V-shaped", "Straight"))   am <- factor(am, labels = c("Automatic", "Manual"))   cyl  <- factor(cyl)   gear <- factor(gear) })  # Graph p1 <- ggplot(mtcars2) +   geom_point(aes(x = wt, y = mpg, colour = gear)) +   labs_e61(     title = "Fuel Economy Declines as Weight Increases",     subtitle = "1973-74",     sources = "1974 Motor Trend US magazine.",     x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",     y = "mpg",     colour = "Gears"   )   graph <- p1 +   theme_e61(adj = -12) +    mplot_label(label = c("3", "4", "5"),               x = c(4, 2.7, 2.5),               y = c(23, 35, 15)) +   scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(0, 40)) +   scale_colour_e61(n = 3) +   add_e61_logo() +    square_legend_symbols()  save_e61(here::here("man/figures/fig-1.svg"), graph)  knitr::include_graphics(here::here("man/figures/fig-1.svg"))

title: Introduction to theme61
code: graph <- p1 +   facet_grid(vs ~ am) +   theme_e61(legend = "bottom", legend_title = TRUE) +   scale_colour_e61(n = 3) +   scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(10, 40)) +   scale_x_continuous_e61()  save_e61(here::here("man/figures/fig-2.svg"), graph)  knitr::include_graphics(here::here("man/figures/fig-2.svg"))

title: Introduction to theme61
code: g <- ggplot(mpg, aes(cty)) +    geom_density(aes(fill = factor(cyl)), linetype = "blank", alpha = 0.8) +   labs_e61(     title = "Distribution of Car City Mileage",     subtitle = "In miles per gallon, by number of cylinders",     sources = "mpg dataset",     x = NULL,     y = "dens",     fill = "No. cylinders"   ) +   mplot_label(label = c("3 cyl", "5 cyl", "6 cyl", "8 cyl"),               x = c(25, 24, 16, 12),               y = c(0.1, 0.35, 0.25, 0.25)) +   theme_e61() +   scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(0, 0.6, 0.2)) +   scale_x_continuous_e61() +   scale_fill_e61(n = 4) +   scale_colour_e61(n = 4) +   add_e61_logo()  save_e61(here::here("man/figures/fig-3.svg"), g)  knitr::include_graphics(here::here("man/figures/fig-3.svg"))

title: Introduction to theme61
code: df <- economics_long[economics_long$variable %in% c("psavert", "uempmed"), ] df <- df[year(df$date) %in% c(1967:1981), ]  # plot graph <- ggplot(df, aes(x = date)) +   geom_line(aes(y = value, colour = variable), size = 1) +   # Not using mplot_label just to show how plot_label works   plot_label("Market returns", "1972-01-01", 17, 2, 1) +   plot_label("Unemployment", "1973-01-01", 3, 2, 2) +   labs_e61(     title = "Time Series of Returns Percentage*",     subtitle = "Drawn from long data format",     footnotes = "Some pointless footnote",     sources = "Economics",     x = NULL, y = "%"   ) +    scale_x_date(date_breaks = "3 years", date_labels = "%Y") +   scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(0, 20, 5)) +   theme_e61() +   scale_colour_e61(2) +   add_e61_logo()  save_e61(here::here("man/figures/fig-4.svg"), graph)  knitr::include_graphics(here::here("man/figures/fig-4.svg"))

title: Introduction to theme61
code: col_data <- head(mtcars2, 8) col_data$names <- rownames(col_data) col_data$index <- 1:nrow(col_data)  graph <- ggplot(col_data, aes(x = index, y = hp, fill = hp)) +   geom_col() +   labs_e61(     title = "Frivolous Filled Column Chart",      subtitle = "For the purpose of showing off the continuous colour palette",     sources = c("e61 Institute", "Another source"),     x = NULL, y = "hp") +   scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(0, 250)) +   theme_e61(legend = "bottom", adj = -15) +   scale_fill_e61(discrete = FALSE, palette = "light")  save_e61(here::here("man/figures/fig-5.svg"), graph)  knitr::include_graphics(here::here("man/figures/fig-5.svg"))

title: Introduction to theme61
code: col_data <- head(mtcars2, 8) col_data$names <- rownames(col_data) col_data$index <- 1:nrow(col_data)  graph <- ggplot(col_data, aes(x = factor(index), y = hp, fill = hp)) +   geom_col() +   coord_flip() +   theme_e61(legend = "bottom") +   labs_e61(     title = "Frivolous Filled Horizontal Bar Chart",      subtitle = "For the purpose of showing off the continuous colour palette",     sources = c("e61 Institute", "Another source"),     x = NULL, y = "hp") +   scale_x_discrete(breaks = 1:8) +   scale_y_continuous_e61(limits = c(0, 250)) +   scale_fill_e61(discrete = FALSE, palette = "light") +    format_flip_bar_charts()  save_e61(here::here("man/figures/fig-6.svg"), graph)  knitr::include_graphics(here::here("man/figures/fig-6.svg"))

code: scale_y_continuous_e61(   limits,   sec_axis = dup_axis(),   y_top = TRUE,   expand_bottom = 0,   expand_top = 0,   ... )  scale_x_continuous_e61(expand_left = 0, expand_right = 0.015, ...)

title: Format axes in the e61 Institute style — scale_y_continuous_e61
text: limits One : NULL use default scale range. numeric vector length two providing minimum maximum   limits scale. numeric vector length three providing limits scale   increment axis tick, e.g. c(0, 25, 5)   set axis range 0 25, increments 5 per tick. sec_axis Adds secondary axis (defaults dup_axis(), duplicates axis), see sec_axis details. Set FALSE hide secondary axis. y_top Logical. Ensures space top y-axis axis label. Defaults TRUE. Set FALSE axis label placed elsewhere. expand_bottom Numeric. Add extra space data points bottom graph. See expansion details. expand_top Numeric. Add extra space data points top graph. ... Arguments passed ggplot2::scale_y_continuous, ggplot2::scale_x_continuous name name scale. Used axis legend title. waiver(), default, name scale taken first mapping used aesthetic. NULL, legend title omitted. labels One : NULL labels waiver() default labels computed transformation object character vector giving labels (must length breaks) expression vector (must length breaks). See ?plotmath details. function takes breaks input returns labels output. Also accepts rlang lambda function notation. expand position scales, vector range expansion constants used add padding around data ensure placed distance away axes. Use convenience function expansion() generate values expand argument. defaults expand scale 5% side continuous variables, 0.6 units side discrete variables. oob One : Function handles limits outside scale limits (bounds). Also accepts rlang lambda function notation. default (scales::censor()) replaces bounds values NA. scales::squish() squishing bounds values range. scales::squish_infinite() squishing infinite values range. na.value Missing values replaced value. trans continuous scales, name transformation object object . Built-transformations include "asn", "atanh", "boxcox", "date", "exp", "hms", "identity", "log", "log10", "log1p", "log2", "logit", "modulus", "probability", "probit", "pseudo_log", "reciprocal", "reverse", "sqrt" "time". transformation object bundles together transform, inverse, methods generating breaks labels. Transformation objects defined scales package, called <name>_trans (e.g., scales::boxcox_trans()). can create transformation scales::trans_new(). guide function used create guide name. See guides() information. position position scales, position axis. left right y axes, top bottom x axes. breaks One : NULL breaks waiver() default breaks computed transformation object numeric vector positions function takes limits input returns breaks output (e.g., function returned scales::extended_breaks()). Also accepts rlang lambda function notation. minor_breaks One : NULL minor breaks waiver() default breaks (one minor break major break) numeric vector positions function given limits returns vector minor breaks. Also accepts rlang lambda function notation. n.breaks integer guiding number major breaks. algorithm may choose slightly different number ensure nice break labels. effect breaks = waiver(). Use NULL use default number breaks given transformation. sec.axis sec_axis() used specify secondary axis. expand_left Numeric. Add extra space data points left graph. expand_right Numeric. Add extra space data points right graph.

Defaults TRUE. palette Character. specific e61 palette continuous scales. Must supplied continuous scale used. ... Arguments passed ggplot2::scale_colour_manual values set aesthetic values map data values . values matched order (usually alphabetical) limits scale, breaks provided. named vector, values matched based names instead. title: Wrapper function to produce e61 style graph titles and footers — labs_e61
code: labs_e61(   title,   subtitle = NULL,   footnotes = NULL,   sources = NULL,   title_max_char = 35,   subtitle_max_char = 45,   footnote_max_char = 55,   title_wrap = TRUE,   subtitle_wrap = TRUE,   footnote_wrap = TRUE,   ... )

title: Wrapper function to produce e61 style graph titles and footers — labs_e61
text: title text title. subtitle text subtitle. footnotes vector footnote text strings. new string prepended *, **, ***, etc. Note need include asterisks title/subtitle . Please sensible number separate points include graph. sources String vector providing names sources graph. title_max_char, subtitle_max_char, footnote_max_char Numeric. Set maximum number characters per line title, subtitle, sources footnotes. default roughly appropriate default graph dimensions e61_save. title_wrap, subtitle_wrap, footnote_wrap Logical. Enables text wrapping title, subtitle, sources footnotes. Defaults TRUE. ... Arguments passed ggplot2::labs alt,alt_insight Text used generation alt-text plot. See get_alt_text examples.

title: Wrapper function to produce e61 style graph titles and footers — labs_e61
text: primary purpose function correctly format footer   text without requiring user guess put manual line breaks   long footnotes put "Sources:" .   transforming footnotes sources arguments nicely   formatted text goes caption argument ggplot2's   labs() function. Thus, using footnotes   sources, supply caption argument well.

title: Wrapper function to produce e61 style graph titles and footers — labs_e61
code: ggplot() +   theme_e61() +   labs_e61(     title = "Graph title*",     subtitle = "Graph subtitle**",     sources = c("A source", "Company name", "Better source"),     footnotes = c("Footnote 1", "Footnote 2")     ) #> Please remember to use ‘scale_y_continuous_e61()’ in conjunction with ‘theme_e61()’ to ensure the graph axes render correctly. This message is shown once per session and may be disabled by setting options('save_e61.message' = FALSE). See ?theme_e61 for more details.

what: Saves ggplot graphs with sensible defaults — save_e61
title: Saves ggplot graphs with sensible defaults — save_e61
text: Designed save ggplot graphs made e61 theme   sensible defaults ensure text size appropriately proportioned   given default sizing. Currently file formats supported .svg (preferred)   .png. SVG modern vector graphics file format means can   scaled size without blurring becoming pixelated. Use   PNG file format rare case vector graphics   supported. See ggsave details custom function arguments.

title: Saves ggplot graphs with sensible defaults — save_e61
code: save_e61(   filename,   plot = ggplot2::last_plot(),   width = NULL,   height = NULL,   resize = NULL,   scale = 1,   dpi = 100,   ... )

title: Saves ggplot graphs with sensible defaults — save_e61
text: filename File name create disk. Remember must provide file extension, e.g. .svg. plot Plot object save. Defaults last plot displayed usually need provide explicitly. width Plot width cm. Defaults 8.5. height Plot height cm. Defaults 9 specify . resize Rescales graph text. Useful need large small graph use vector graphics format. works saving PNG file format. value 2 doubles graph dimensions. ... Arguments passed ggplot2::ggsave scale Multiplicative scaling factor. dpi Plot resolution. Also accepts string input: "retina" (320), "print" (300), "screen" (72). Applies raster output types.

title: Saves ggplot graphs with sensible defaults — save_e61
text: Setting correct height width parameters quite difficult   due way ggplot translates ggplot objects pixels   physical dimensions (inches centimetres). Font sizes also   transformed differently graph elements adds another   dimension difficulty. save_e61 generally requires   provide height width arguments trial error,   produces loud messages stick defaults, tried   make terrible. width/height arguments , file output   excess space left/right top/bottom (values high),   graph shrunk look weird (values   low).

code: theme_e61(   y_top = TRUE,   adj = -12,   fix_left = 0,   legend = c("none", "bottom", "top", "left", "right"),   legend_title = FALSE,   aspect_ratio = 0.75,   panel_borders = TRUE,   background = "white",   base_size = 10,   base_family = "Arial",   base_line_size = points_to_mm(0.75),   base_rect_size = points_to_mm(1) )

title: e61 themed graph options — theme_e61
text: y_top Defaults TRUE. Moves y-axis title top. adj Either single numeric adjust left right axis titles simultaneously vector 2 numerics adjust axis title separately. negative values move text closer graph panel. Defaults -12 seems work well y-axis 1-3 character-wide values. fix_left Optional. Sometimes value adj argument negative, margins left side graph start cut text. Provide small positive value (5?) correct . legend Character. Legend position, use "none" (default) hide legend. legend_title Logical. Include Legend title? Defaults FALSE. aspect_ratio Numeric. Sets aspect ratio graph panel. panel_borders Logical. Show panel borders? Defaults TRUE. background Character. Options "white" (default) "grey". base_size Numeric. Chart font size. Default 10. base_family Character. Chart font family. Default Arial. base_line_size Numeric. Default line width. base_rect_size Numeric. Default rect width.

title: theme61 0.3.1
text: 15 Mar 2023 Refactored mplot_label() use plot_label() underlying function rather data.frame geom_text(). fixed two bugs function throws error colour aesthetic ggplot() aes x argument automatically converting dates. Changed colour palette third colour now dark blue rather grey.

title: theme61 0.3.0
text: 09 Mar 2023 Add new function format_flip_bar_charts() applies formatting needed make horizontal bar graphs pretty. Add new functions plot_label() mplot_label() make easier add -graph plot labels. mplot_label() vectorised version lets multiple labels one function. Add new function add_zeroline() add appropriately formatted black line along zero y-axis. New functionality scale_y_continuous_e61() specify break intervals directly limits argument. New vignette explaining use -graph labelling legends. Add new messages information save_e61() try explain users need set dimensions get good graph aesthetics. Add argument turn text wrapping labs_e61(). Add argument change aspect ratio theme_e61(). Change default dimension behaviour save_e61() make graphs look sensible 8.5 cm widths (corresponds half width Word document). Change base_size graph text font size readable 8.5 cm widths. Remove y_title_top_e61() incorporate functionality directly theme_e61() default. Users can choose disable behaviour y_top = FALSE argument. Update Getting Started vignette showcase new functionality. Fix issue labels argument scale_colour/fill_e61() working. minor improvements functions, messages documentation.

title: theme61 0.2.1
text: 20 Dec 2022 Minor adjustments title/footnote font size default max character width account new fixed aspect ratio.

title: theme61 0.2.0
text: 14 Dec 2022 Adds base map function e61_map() sensible defaults mapping. Improvements automatic discrete colour palette selection. Changes theme fix graphs 0.75 aspect ratio. Added alternate minimal theme called theme_e61_clean(). New add-creates charts based esquisse. Updated save_e61() allow save plots recently generated one. Many functions renamed closely align existing ggplot2 function names, _e61 appended , example e61_colour_manual now becomes scale_colour_e61. old functions now deprecated made defunct future versions. Please stop using use new functions instead.

title: theme61 0.1.0
text: 13 May 2022 first functional release theme61 containing everything need make graph e61 style. includes ggplot functions customise theme, axes graph elements. Implements e61 Institute colour palette scale_colour/fill_* function provides colour names data files manual access required. Save functions ensure default graphs appropriate sizing dimensions.
